instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message:
My customer came in with his 11" Air soaked in milk. After drying it would power on with no backlight.

Under the microscope, there was heavy damage and corrosion around <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. I started with a reflow but the chip was not behaving as expected on the BGA, so I removed it for inspection. Sure enough, both pins on the <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> circuit were blown off.

I replaced the badly damaged <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board. This was the closest donor I had available - was this a mistake? I ran a jumper wire from B1 and B2 to the diode side of L7701 around the other side of the board. Now the board does not power up at all and the magsafe LED remains orange.

I will be home from ERC tomorrow and will be going over this board again - just wondering if my attempted repair could have caused the new problems? The board is heavily damaged from the milk, so it would not be surprising at all if something else crapped out in the meantime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message: Need to check voltages, is PPBUS even there now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message:
IS

I've been out of town since last Friday so I was using the past-tense just speaking from memory. I'll update the thread tomorrow with power rail measurements once I'm back in the shop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message:
I don't see any damage around the diagnostic port but removed it anyway. I've already run it through the sonic cleaner so it's hard to see problem areas. Testing a few power rails, I found the following measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = cycles slowly between 8.59V and 8.39V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 14.98V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.421V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.228V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.314V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.421V

Magsafe light still orange, fan does not spin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message: Well if <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is there then the machine is trying to power on. If <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is there then <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> should be there too, short on the rail?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message:
Yup - dead short to ground, measuring 0.002V in diode mode on multiple 5V rails so far:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>


I pulled the <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> I had previously installed & jumped, short still exists. Also pulled several caps on each line which were pretty nasty looking. After removing <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> I'm injecting 5V to the rail to search for the short, it is currently pulling ~850 milliamps.

Edit 2: It was <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>

Thanks for the tips, will update if anything else is weird

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Orange light, no power after attempted backlight repair
threads.message: <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> fried because of short on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, probably bad soldered backlight IC.
